comments.commentBody: Great stuff, thanks. Which merchants do you get that kind of yield from with Discover? No-names, or real ones?

The dirty little secret is that AmEx Membership Rewards is one of the most diluted rewards programs out there -- particularly if you have a card that only gets MR Express, but even if you have regular MR or the MR First program for platinum cards.

I suspect that what's going on with the gift cards is that Zappos, for instance, sells AmEx a gift card with a face value of $50 -- but only charges AmEx $35, for instance, because it knows that a certain percentage of gift card recipients will forget about the gift card or lose it and it will never be redeemed. At least some of the gift cards will end up being given away, possibly to someone who has never shopped at Zappos before, so they might help recruit a new customer who will return to Zappos without a gift card. And of course many customers who do redeem will end up buying something that costs much more than $50 and Zappos's margin might be enough to help cover the discount Zappos gave to AmEx on the gift card.

With Amazon.com purchases, by contrast, AmEx/Amazon.com know that the cardholder is definitely redeeming the points -- their MR account won't get charged until they actually buy something -- and since there's no tangible gift card there's no possibility that an AmEx cardholder who likes Amazon will give a physical card to someone who's never shopped at Amazon before. So AmEx can only pay Amazon.com how much it pays everyone else. Presumably the 7/10 valuation indicates that AmEx often gets at least a 30% discount on gift cards. (I say at least 30%, because it's possible that Amazon still offered AmEx a small discount or side payment since Amazon's inclusion in AmEx MR brochures help to promote Amazon even for non-rewards purchases.)

Contrary to AmEx's stingy program, most major credit card issuers offer a cash back redemption option on their points-based rewards programs, and those redemption options often deliver more value to the consumer. Chase Ultimate Rewards offers cash back redemption at the exact same valuation as gift cards; 2500 points gets you $25 in cash or a $25 gift card, whichever you prefer. Discover actually offers higher valuations with gift cards; for example, you can redeem 25 cash back points for $25 in cash -- or for the same number of points get a $50 gift card from certain merchants. (That should give you an idea of how much of a discount AmEx is actually getting on the gift cards it then resells to cardholders at full price.) Bank of America WorldPoints, CitiBank's ThankYou Network, and Wells Fargo also offer cash back redemption options.
Great stuff, thanks. Which merchants do you get that kind of yield from with Discover? No-names, or real ones?

I am greatly disappointed in former President Carter's charges, he brings against the memory of the late Senator Kennedy. I think former President Carter was one of our finest Presidents, I only wish he could have shown some respect for a man, who isn't able to defend himself. This was a very sad turn of events for a man, whom I always thought to be a christian and a gentleman. In the end, he squabbles with a dead man.

Wow!  Obama just doesn't get it.  His attacks on business and investors are the major reason we are seeing 9.6% unemployment.  I don't think he understands how frightening it is for most of us to see him use the power of government to attack the businesses and corporations who have brought us so much prosperity.  As a small business owner myself, I'm looking forward to seeing the voters reject Obama's job-killing agenda.

But, jacobi, the losing bets of capital allocations to corporate restructurings and commercial real estate dwarf the loans made on modest properties to marginal borrowers.

Why do the rich always blame the poor for their own excesses?

When a president like Carter and Obama's popularity is low, they decide to hold a "peace summit" between middle eastern enemies. We give them millions and they declare what great peacemakers they are (peace prize...). Then the countries buy weapons with our money and when the money is gone, they continue to fight and kill each other all over again.

The more I learn about Castle, the more convinced I am that the Republican primary voters in DE made the right choice.  With Tea Party folks in office, we should be able to start chipping away at this terrible 9.6% unemployment rate.

As a political scientist, I can affirm that Jeff Zeleny is quite right.  It is historically significant that that 55% of respondents to the NYT poll indicate that they are opposed to their own member of Congress.  To me, this is evidence that the new Tea Party ideology - healthy fear of big government - is taking hold and expressing itself.  The bottom line, however, is that the Democrats are getting killed by the 9.6% unemployment rate.

I don't get it. Isn't this like the pot calling the kettle black? While Obama ran for Pres., he said, "I am running to tell the lobbyists in Washington that their days of setting the agenda are over. They have not funded my campaign. They won't work in my White House." But he allowed them first to work on his transition team and to work in the White House. Humph ... who do lobbyist represent? It's rhetorical.

While I may opt to vote for "None of the Above," as a write-in, this particular administration has made it impossible to see this election not as “a choice between sliding backwards and moving forward,” but as a choice between one well backed party or another. That doesn't represent choice to me but continues the long voting premise of voting for the lesser of the evils. Personally, I'm sick and tired of having to do just that - they're all evil choices.

I believe Obama is correct. Now, big business will have its hand in political races and support those who agree with them. The Supreme Court prior ruling should be reconsidered. There is already a considerable amount of corruption in government. This will only enhance the instances for collusion between big business and elected officials.

http://www.cmrji.com/Corruption.html

I love Don and Nacho trying to educate the "Hoover Revisionist", Madison, who has it all figured out ... except for most of the technical details.

But the end of Don's statement struck me, " The fundamental problem with simply making stuff, my overheated friend, simply to regain power is that when and if your regain power--the underlying reality will be there waiting to bite you in the backside."

I don't agree. They simply continue a never-ending quest to find those who must pay, who are to blame. This is exactly what will happen as the Tealoban take over America. When they run out of scapegoats, it will be time to turn the key and push the red button on more distant scapegoats. Introspection and Self-assessment died in these people long long ago in the formative years.

Yes, some of the rest of the word understands that democracy itself requires ground rules, it doesn't function on a lessez-faire basis with equal time given to every theory, with or without tangible support by measurable data.
That $119 million is a lot to spend on a losing cause. And, there are seven weeks remaining for her "Buy It Now" mentality to add at least $30 million more.

Thankfully, Whitman's spending is forcing Democrats to defend a race that they assumed they had in the bag.  This move leaves Democrats elsewhere in the nation starved for cash.  Since it looks like Republicans have already won the House of Representatives, I think Meg Whitman is a hero and that her investment is having a profound impact on saving our nation from socialism.  I don't think we can take anymore of this 9.6% unemployment.
Producing miracles is a tough act to sustain.
In the matter of gerrymandering, America the Stupid once again demonstrates utter cluelessness to positive feedback effects that drive a system into instability and chaos.
We all have the value set at the margin, so none of us can do anything.

The bloodsucking cable tv providers charge me extra for a programmable HDTV set-top box. Why don't I have the liberty to exclude Rupert Murdoch's mind-rotting drivel from my bill? Who else resents this bloodsucker's evident hold over the entire political system giving him the power to extort us in this fashion?

In his dissent, Justice Stevens said the majority had committed a grave error in treating corporate speech the same as that of human beings.

Right now most of you will agree with me that our political system is broken. What we currently have is: the politics of destruction; special interest groups who have the power and money to dictate policy; politicians who must spend their time raising money for the next election instead of doing the People's business; and, there are those who are so concerned about getting re-elected they cede their responsibilities to the citizenry to those groups making the loudest noises and the greatest threats.

Please visit http://thompsoninthehouse.blogspot.com and I hope you will share it with others. You’ll learn about my past experiences that have helped to shape my core values and beliefs. And, you will know my positions on important issues facing Ohio and our Nation.

Jacquelyn K. Thompson
Candidate Ohio House District 20

Given what she has spent in her campaign to win election as California's governor, Meg Whitman should be closely scruntized on several questions. Is her willingness to rack up campaign expenses a precusor for how she will mange California's budget?

If not, then: exactly how much will she cut the state's budgets for schools? Exactly what bureaucratic positions will get the axe? Why have a group of California economists called your proposed economic policies "fundamentally unsound?" Why has a report issued by your campaign on the costs of state regulations been called "essentially useless?" Why would you suspend a clean energy act that is actually "creating jobs?" Will cutting 30,000 state jobs save the $15 billion of California's projected budget deficit for next year? If you elminate the state's capital gains tax how will you make up the $10 billion short fall?

Both eager and skeptical voters want to know.
--Walter Rhett

#37 - Eugene Gorrin

I started writing about my experiences regarding affirmative action on this blog largely because so many folks were suggesting that it was irrational for someone like me to vote for the Republican party. I like to stress the affirmative action issue because it is a very obvious case of how the Democrat party is hostile to poor, white voters - like me as a young man. I don't mind calling attention to my award-winning doctorate either, since so many of the people who post here seem to assume that independents and conservatives are uninformed about politics. My job, as far as it goes, is to confront stereotypes with more accurate and timely information. I'm grateful the NYT has given me this opportunity. The larger issue is that President Obama's policies have left us with a 9.6% unemployment problem. I know from the day-to-day experience of my wife's job search that this is an extremely painful issue for many families right now. Personally, I was harmed as a young scholar by the work of both Michelle and Barack Obama to substitute African-American professors for more highly qualified Armenian-American professors. :) Since I knew the young Obama, I guess I feel especially betrayed by this effort. Historically, however, I know that those who hold to Marxist revolutionary philosophy have little regard for the "little people" harmed by their efforts. I'm glad to do what I can now to prevent a second generation of young men and women from being harmed by the Democrat party the way I was so severely injured...

Right now most of you will agree with me that our political system is broken. What we currently have is: the politics of destruction; special interest groups who have the power and money to dictate policy; politicians who must spend their time raising money for the next election instead of doing the People's business; and, there are those who are so concerned about getting re-elected they cede their responsibilities to the citizenry to those groups making the loudest noises and the greatest threats.

Please visit http://thompsoninthehouse.blogspot.com and I hope you will share it with others. You’ll learn about my past experiences that have helped to shape my core values and beliefs. And, you will know my positions on important issues facing Ohio and our Nation, including the death penalty.

A viable alternative to the status quo.

Jacquelyn K. Thompson
Candidate for Ohio House District 20

Discover has more than 100 participating merchants, including many well-known merchants. Just a few examples: You can double the value of your rewards at car rental companies (Alamo, Enterprise, National); gift companies (FTD, Mrs. Field's); and several cruise lines (Carnival, Celebrity, Norwegian, Princess, and Royal Caribbean); and at least one hotel chain (Hyatt). There are fixed redemption amounts that vary by merchant. The car rental companies generally offer $40 gift cards for 20 points, for example, whereas most cruise lines offer either a $80 card for 40 points or a $120 card for 60 points. There are several other well-known merchants that offer smaller bonuses. Clothes stores like Banana Republic, Brooks Brothers, Old Navy, American Eagle, Eddie Bauer, Gap, Lands' End, Nike, Old Navy, and L.L. Bean offer $50 gift cards for 40 points, or $25 cards for 20 points, for example.

The one downside of Discover's offer is that they only give you 0.25% rewards on your first $3000 of spending in a year, and the 5% bonus categories (which can sometimes change as frequently as monthly) have such low limits that it's hardly worth the hassle it takes to sign up. The fourth quarter 5% bonus categories have a limit of $300, for instance. This has made me more of a fan of the Chase Freedom card, which has started offering 5% bonuses on up to $1500 in spending each quarter. Chase also gives at least a full 1% reward on all other spending without the $3000 haircut and has no annual fee, so it's a decent option for people who may not be big spenders. Unlike Discover, Chase does not offer higher face value rewards if you redeem for gift cards, but they do make it easy to redeem for cash (or anything else) at full value -- no dilution like AmEx has.

Like AmEx, a lot of issuers try to dilute the value of points so most consumers (particularly lower-spending consumers) get less than one cent of cash value for their points. Chase and Discover seem to be the least diluted as far as redemption options go.

The short NYT piece appears not to incorporate some important segments of the Jimmy Carter "60 Minutes" interview.  So I will be eagerly awaiting its showing this coming Sunday.  I hope that, for the sake of everyone involved, there is a bit more to this story than the NYT piece indicates.  Also, I'd like to know more about the proposed Carter healthcare legislation, and why Kennedy may have opposed it (other than for reasons of personal spite).  What kind of healthcare industry might we find ourselves with right now if the Carter plan had been implemented, and how much might we as a nation be spending on this industry?

The fact is former President Carter was a failure as president domestically and internationally his poor handling of the situation as it unfolded in Iran during his tenure has led us to our current problems in Iraq and Iran.

Former President Carter should not criticize Ted Kennedy a year after his death when he can no longer defend himself.
